column1: The '''Book of Mazarbul''' was the record of [[Balin]]'s return to [[Moria]] with a group of [[Durin's Folk|Longbeards]] in [[Third Age]] {{TA|2989}}.
==History==
The Book of Mazarbul was begun in {{TA|2989}}
column2: upon Balin's return to Moria. The book recounted a battle with the [[Orcs]] that inhabited the old halls of Khazad-dûm
column3: in which [[Balin]]'s Dwarves were victorious. They settled in the Twenty-first Hall
column5: and Balin himself ruled his new domain from the old Chamber of Records
column6: also called the [[Chamber of Mazarbul]]. Over the next five years
column7: the [[Dwarves]] seem to have settled quite successfully into their new home
column8: exploring under the Mountains as far as the [[Doors of Durin|West-gate of Moria]]
column9: and recovering [[Durin's Axe]] and apparently other priceless items made of ''[[mithril]]''. These feats were recorded in the book.

column1: The Lordship of Balin was short-lived. [[Ori]]
column2: who was with him in Moria
column3: recorded in the last pages of the Book how an army of Orcs came unexpectedly out of the east
column4: slaying Balin outside the [[Great Gates|East-gate]]. The Dwarves defended themselves
column5: but they were beleaguered from the east by the Orcs
column6: and from the west by the mysterious [[Watcher in the Water]]. Their last stand was in the Chamber of Mazarbul
column7: where the Orcs eventually overcame and destroyed them. As there was no hope to escape
column8: Ori continued writing in the book
column9: hoping that someone would find it
column10: and would know what happened to them.<ref>{{PM|XNotes}}

column1: The victorious Orcs seem not to have understood the significance of the Book
column2: so that rather than carrying it off or destroying it
column3: they left it to rot in the Chamber. There it was found twenty-four years later by the [[Fellowship of the Ring|Company of the Ring]]
column6: and missing a number of pages
column7: but still readable in some parts. [[Gandalf]] passed it to [[Gimli]] to return to King [[Dáin Ironfoot|Dáin]]
column8: after which nothing more is heard about it. If Gimli was able to keep it through the battles that followed
column9: and didn't discard it with his gear at [[Parth Galen]]
column10: it is possible that he carried it throughout his travels in [[Middle-earth]]
column11: returning it at last to Dáin's heir [[Thorin Stonehelm|Thorin III]] in [[Lonely Mountain|Erebor]].

column1: ==Composition Details==
The Book of Mazarbul was written by many different authors
column2: using [[Cirth]] of Moria and Dale as well as Elvish [[Tengwar]] letters. The pages of the book were marked with numbers referring to the years after Balin's arrival in Moria.

column1: ===Third Page===
[[File:J.R.R. Tolkien - Mazarbul page 2.jpg|150px|thumb|The first sample page of the Book of Mazarbul made by Tolkien.]]
The first page [[Gandalf]] read in the Book of Mazarbul was marked ''one-three''
column2: so at least two were missing from the beginning.

column1: This page was written using [[Angerthas Erebor]] as in a diary
column2: written quickly without attempt at calligraphy or meticulous consistency of spelling. In writing the Common Speech
column3: the Dwarves tended to blend its usual spelling with certain idiosyncratic phonetic usages (the Dwarves did not like to use any letter or rune in more than one value
column4: nor to express a simple sound by combinations of letters). This page was numbered at the top with the runic numeral "three".<ref>''[[Pictures by J.R.R. Tolkien]]''
column5: ''[[The Treason of Isengard]]'' and ''[[J.R.R. Tolkien: Artist and Illustrator]]''.</ref>

column1: The page read the following. Many parts are not readable
column2: and the parts in italic are those which Gandalf could not make out in the dim light of Moria.<ref>A translation of what is readable on this page

column1: We drove out the orcs from the Great Gate and guardroom ''and took the [[First Hall]]''. We slew many in the bright sun in the dale. [[Flói]] was killed by an arrow. He slew the great ''chieftain''[...] Flói under grass near [[Mirrormere]] [...] ''came [...]ken we repaired'' [...] We have taken the [[Twenty-first Hall]] of North End to dwell in. There is ''good air [...] that can easily be watched [...] the'' shaft ''is clear [...]'' [[Balin]] has set up his seat in the Chamber of Mazarbul [...] ''gathered'' [...] gold [...] ''wonderful lay'' [[Durin's Axe]] [...] ''silver'' helm. ''Balin has taken them for his own.'' Balin is now [[lord of Moria]]. [''Gandalf assumes this is the end of a chapter''] [...] ''today'' we found truesilver [...] well-forged ''helm[...]n[...]coat made all of purest'' [[mithril]] [...] [[Óin]] to seek for the upper armories of the [[Third Deep]] [...] go westwards to s[...] to [[Doors of Durin|Hollin gate]].
===Year five===
[[File:J.R.R. Tolkien - Mazarbul page 1.jpg|150px|thumb|The second sample page of the Book of Mazarbul made by Tolkien.]]
Gandalf skimmed through the rest of the book; Gandalf notes that the pages begin to be numbered "five"
column2: meaning the fifth year of the colony. This second page was written using [[Tengwar]] of the later Westron convention which used full letters for vowels. Gandalf described the text as written by "a large bold hand using an Elvish script"
column3: which Gimli describes as [[Ori]]'s hand. The runic figure at the bottom of the page is the numeral "five".

An orc shot him from behind a stone. We slew the orc, but many more ''ca(me) [...]'' up from east up the [[Celebrant|Silverlode]] [...] ''we rescued Balin’s body [...]re a sharp battle [...]'' we have barred the gates ''but doubt if [...]'' can hold them long. If ''there is [...] no escape it will be a'' horrible ''fate to'' suffer, ''but I shall hold''.

===Last Page===
[[Image:J.R.R. Tolkien - Mazarbul.jpg|150px|thumb|The third sample page of the Book of Mazarbul made by Tolkien.]]
The last page of the Book of Mazarbul was read aloud by Gandalf. It is written in [[Angerthas Erebor]], similar to that of the first page, but with a different hand and different details in the runes.

We cannot get out. We cannot get out. They have taken the bridge and [[Second Hall]]. [[Frár]] and [[Lóni]] and [[Náli]] fell there bravely while the rest retreated to Mazarbul. We still hold the chamber but hope is fading now. [[Óin]]’s party went five days ago but today only four returned. The pool is up to the wall at West-gate. The [[Watcher in the Water]] took Óin -- we cannot get out. The end comes soon. We hear drums
column2: drums in the deep."

column1: The last line is a trailing scrawl of elf-letters reads "They are coming".
==Inspiration==
Tolkien comments on his general treatment of the Book of Mazarbul pages: "...the text was cast into English spelt as at present
column2: but modified as it might be by writers in haste whose familiarity with the written form was imperfect
column3: and who were also (on the first and third pages) transliterating the English into a different alphabet."; "...since documents of this kind nearly always show uses of letters or shapes that are peculiar and rarely or never found elsewhere
column4: a few such features are also introduced...".

column1: The use of English to represent the Common Speech in primary sources such as the pages of the Book of Mazarbul was a result of Tolkien's vision of completely translating all Westron into modern English
column2: even in authentic documentation
column3: although upon reflection Tolkien said that this translation was "an erroneous extension of the general linguistic treatment"<ref>{{HM|PM}}

column1: Thus
column2: the Book of Mazarbul showcases some slightly different distributions of certain English sounds.

column1: ==Etymology==
{{main|mazarbul (word)}}
Mazarbul means "records" in [[Khuzdul]]. This name was used in connection with the Chamber of Records of [[Moria|Khazad-dûm]] and the Book of Records found in that chamber.

:A detailed prop was made from the movie
column2: with Cirth and Tengwar letters written perhaps by [[Daniel Reeve]].

column1: :The outside cover of the prop reads: "Records (of the) Longbeards of Khazad-dûm"

:The first page of the book read by Gandalf in the movie is written using [[Cirth]] (Angerthas Erebor) and Tengwar (full mode). A number of leaves before this page fall out when Gandalf opens the book. This apparently is the second to the last page. The translation is as follows:
* Cirth: "And so we come to our final hope. Óin is going to the West-gate to see if we can escape that way."

* Tengwar: "The orcs have taken all the lower levels and the upper halls to the fifth level. Our stores of food are running low and we have no water to drink. Unless Oin can find a way out at the West-gate
column2: we are doomed whether the orcs get us or not."

The Watcher in the Water took Óin...we cannot get out. The end comes soon. We hear drums

:What Gandalf is reading seemingly does not always correspond with the page he is viewing when doing so. He also "reads" a few lines not seen in the viewable pages. It has been suggested that Gandalf was glancing simultaneously at three pages of text
column2: reading all the while to the Fellowship. In other words
column3: he was composing a summary quickly from three separate pages
column4: perhaps including one of the pages that fell out of the book when he opened it. "We have barred the gates but cannot hold them for long" is a phrase from Tolkien's second sample page of the Book of Mazarbul
column5: so this is likely from one the pages that initially fell out of the book.
